options.text: By setting up survey stations and using a laser to measure distances

options.label: C
options.text: By drawing a map by hand

title: How to sequence the human genome - Mark J. Kiel

multiple-choice.question: What is a genome?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A collection of tissues in an organism

options.label: D
options.text: A collection of organs in an organism

What is the code that cells use to know how to behave?

options.label: A
options.text: To know the sequence of letters that make up a protein

options.label: B
options.text: To know the sequence of letters that make up a gene

options.label: C
options.text: To know the sequence of letters that make up a genome

options.label: D
options.text: To know the sequence of letters that make up a cell

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists increase the signal they can detect from each individual letter of DNA?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By using special colored letters to bind to the DNA

options.label: D
options.text: By taking pictures of each snippet of genome

options.label: A
options.text: To decipher what the sequence means

options.label: B
options.text: To make thousands of copies of each genome piece

options.label: C
options.text: To take pictures of each snippet of genome

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The way we think about how we treat each other

options.label: C

title: High-altitude wind energy from kites! - Saul Griffith

multiple-choice.question: What was George Pocock's contribution to the history of kites in 1827?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: He pioneered the use of kites for towing buggies in races against horse carriages.

options.label: C
options.text: He developed the control systems for powered human flight.

options.label: D
options.text: He wrote a seminal paper on using kites to generate electricity.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It can only generate electricity at lower altitudes.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is less efficient than a fixed-wing turbine.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To generate megawatt-scale power at 2,000 feet altitude

options.label: D
options.text: To generate 100 megawatts of power at 10,000 feet altitude

title: What makes us feel good about our work? - Dan Ariely

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the common assumption about why people work?

options.label: A
options.text: People work for personal fulfillment and a sense of purpose.

options.label: B
options.text: People work solely for financial gain.

options.label: C
options.text: People work to contribute to society.

options.label: D
options.text: People work for recognition and praise.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Sisyphic condition" in the context of the Lego experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition where participants build Legos with a sense of purpose.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where participants build Legos without any meaning or purpose.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where participants build Legos for a reward.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where participants build Legos in a team.

options.label: A
options.text: Participants in the meaningful condition built fewer Bionicles than those in the Sisyphic condition.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants in the meaningful condition built the same number of Bionicles as those in the Sisyphic condition.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants in the meaningful condition built more Bionicles than those in the Sisyphic condition.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants in the Sisyphic condition built no Bionicles.

options.label: A
options.text: There was a strong positive correlation.

options.label: B
options.text: There was a weak positive correlation.

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: Participants in the acknowledged condition stopped working at a lower pay rate than those in the shredder condition.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants in the acknowledged condition stopped working at the same pay rate as those in the shredder condition.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants in the shredder condition did not stop working.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency for people to undervalue things they have built or created themselves.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: In the experiment with the origami, what was the result in terms of the amount participants were willing to pay for their own origami?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants were willing to pay less for their own origami than for someone else's origami.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants were willing to pay the same amount for their own origami as for someone else's origami.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants were willing to pay more for their own origami than for someone else's origami.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants were not willing to pay anything for their own origami.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between Adam Smith's and Karl Marx's views on labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Adam Smith emphasized the importance of efficiency, while Karl Marx emphasized the importance of meaning and connection to one's work.

options.label: B
options.text: Adam Smith emphasized the importance of meaning and connection to one's work, while Karl Marx emphasized the importance of efficiency.

options.label: C
options.text: Adam Smith and Karl Marx both emphasized the importance of efficiency and meaning in labor.

options.label: D
options.text: Adam Smith and Karl Marx both emphasized the importance of payment and motivation in labor.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key takeaway from the experiments and discussions on labor and motivation?

options.label: A
options.text: Payment and motivation are the only important factors in labor.

options.label: B
options.text: Meaning, creation, challenges, ownership, identity, and pride are also important factors in labor, in addition to payment and motivation.

options.label: C
options.text: Efficiency is the most important factor in labor.

options.label: D
options.text: Labor is solely driven by financial gain.

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Odd - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Lady - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel
